etymology.description: Pictogram: a writing brush; later the inverted brush was misread as 又 and moved to the top (form 𰠄) to avoid confusion with 袁 (衣+又).
etymology.interpretation: Early graphs depicted a brush; over time, an upside-down brush shape was reinterpreted as the hand/component 又, prompting scribes to reposition it above. The original image became obscured, while meanings like “to end” and the noun “soldier” developed through later semantic shift and loan usage.

examples.chinese: 他把卒推进一步(他把卒推進一步)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ zú tuī jìn yí bù.
examples.english: He advanced the pawn one step.

examples.chinese: 他卒于去年冬天(他卒於去年冬天)。
计划卒成(計劃卒成)，大家松了口气(大家鬆了口氣)。
examples.pinyin: Jìhuà zúchéng, dàjiā sōng le kǒuqì.
examples.english: The plan was completed, and everyone breathed a sigh of relief.
